ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about definitions and examples of misconduct in the scientific community. Topics included sexual harassment, abuse of power by superiors, plagiarism, falsification of data, fabrication of data, cheating, and publishing scandals.
Lots of research experience, how to think like a chemist, plan out experiments, troubleshoot and not be bothered with failure.
I learned a lot of the history of ethical breaches/violations in scientific research.
How to be an independent scientist and develop new ideas. Also, Parr reminded me not to lie, cheat, steal, or have nonconsentual sex.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Clear lectures, interesting examples, required for NSF funding, low workload.

Weaknesses: None.
Engaging. Learn real skills. Not too much at home work.
Wish there was a syllabus with all the required readings for the week so we know what we have to do before hand.
This class is good as is.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: There is no question of recommendation because the only people allowed to take this course are those who are required to. That said, this course will teach you all of the ethics you need to know to conduct research, in a very low-stakes and low-stress environment. There is minimal work, and Parr is a great instructor.
Yes. Its required but youll learn a lot and as long as you choose something interesting, youll enjoy the work.

Yes! if you like chemistry research this is the class to be in. Experiences will vary greatly based on your PI and grad-student/post-doc mentor so make sure to get into a good lab with a nice/caring PI and a nice/caring mentor. (My PI didn't make ppl write end-of-semester reports but there were some other PI who seemed to enjoy giving students stress with end-of-semester reports that they got a B on RIP). You will do lots of research, fail in lots of your experiments and succeed in some, and learn a TON.
It's a great way to learn about ethical research.
This is the chemsitry senior thesis. If you are a BS/Int./BSMS, you have to take it. Why else would you otherwise?
